org.jcvi.jillion.core.datastore

Interface DataStore<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Closeable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    AceFileDataStore, AsmContigDataStore, AsmUnitigDataStore, CasGappedReferenceDataStore, ContigDataStore<PR,C>, CtgContigDataStore, DataStoreUtil.CacheableDataStore<T>, FastaDataStore<S,T,F,D>, FastqDataStore, FastqFileDataStore, FragmentDataStore, NucleotideFastaDataStore, NucleotideFastaFileDataStore, NucleotideSequenceDataStore, PhdDataStore, PositionFastaDataStore, PositionSequenceDataStore, ProteinFastaDataStore, ProteinFastaFileDataStore, ProteinSequenceDataStore, QualityFastaDataStore, QualitySequenceDataStore, SamFileDataStore, ScaffoldDataStore, SffFileDataStore, TasmContigDataStore, TigrContigDataStore, TraceDataStore<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractDataStore, AbstractLargeFastaFileDataStore, AbstractMapBackedDataStore, AdaptedFastaDataStore, AdaptedNucleotideFastaDataStore, DefaultFragmentDataStore, HighLowAceContigPhdDatastore, IndexedFragmentDataStore, IndexedProteinFastaFileDataStore.Impl, IndexedQualityFastaFileDataStore.Impl, LargeProteinFastaFileDataStore, LargeQualityFastaFileDataStore, PhdDirDataStore

    public interface DataStore<T>
extends Closeable
    A DataStore is an interface which represents a repository of entity records which can be fetched by a unique (to this DataStore) id. How the data in the datastore is stored is implementation dependent.

    NOTE: DataStores have a method iterator() but do not implement Iterable. This is because if the returned StreamingIterator throws an exception, client code may not always be able to properly clean up resources by explicitly closing the iterator returned by syntatic-sugar uses of Iterables. Not closing a StreamingIterator in a finally block (or Java 7 try-with resource) can cause deadlock or blocked threads. For example, DataStores have been designed not to work with syntatic-sugar uses of Iterables such as the Java 5 for-each loop construct. The code below will not compile since DataStore does not implement Iterable: 

     //not allowed since can't directly
 //access iterator to close if throws Exception
 for(T record : datastore){
   ...
 }
    Author:
    dkatzel

      • Methods inherited from interface java.io.Closeable

        close

    • Method Detail

      • idIterator

        StreamingIterator<String> idIterator()
                              throws DataStoreException
        Create a new StreamingIterator which will iterate over the ids of all the records in this DataStore. The iteration order is guaranteed to match the iteration order by iterator(). The StreamingIterator is only valid while this DataStore is open. If the StreamingIterator is still not finished iterating when this DataStore is closed via Closeable.close(), then any calls to StreamingIterator.hasNext() or StreamingIterator.next() will throw DataStoreClosedException.
        Returns:
        a new StreamingIterator instance; never null and never contain any null elements, but could be empty if getNumberOfRecords() == 0.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this iterator.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.

      • ids

        default ThrowingStream<String> ids()
                            throws DataStoreException
        Get the ids of all the records as a ThrowingStream.
        API Note:
        this is the same as idIterator().toThrowingStream().
        Returns:
        a new ThrowingStream; will never be null, and never contain null elements but may be empty.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this iterator.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.
        Since:
        5.3

      • get

        T get(String id)
throws DataStoreException
        Get the record in this DataStore with the given id.
        Parameters:
        id - the id of the object to fetch; may not be null.
        Returns:
        the object being fetched, will be null if contains(id) is false.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem fetching the data from this DataStore.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.
        NullPointerException - if id is null.

      • contains

        boolean contains(String id)
          throws DataStoreException
        Does this DataStore contain an object with the given id.
        Parameters:
        id - the id of the object to check for containment; may not be null.
        Returns:
        true if an object with this id exists; false otherwise.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem fetching the data from this DataStore.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.
        NullPointerException - if id is null.

      • getNumberOfRecords

        long getNumberOfRecords()
                 throws DataStoreException
        Get the total number of objects in this DataStore.
        Returns:
        the number of objects in this DataStore; always ≥ 0.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem fetching the data from this DataStore.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.

      • isClosed

        boolean isClosed()
        Checks to see if this DataStore been closed by the Closeable.close() method.
        Returns:
        true if this DataStore is closed; false otherwise.

      • iterator

        StreamingIterator<T> iterator()
                       throws DataStoreException
        Create a new StreamingIterator which will iterate over all the records in this DataStore. The iteration order is guaranteed to match the iteration order by idIterator(). The StreamingIterator is only valid while this DataStore is open. If the StreamingIterator is still not finished iterating when this DataStore is closed via Closeable.close(), then any calls to StreamingIterator.hasNext() or StreamingIterator.next() will throw DataStoreClosedException.
        Returns:
        a new StreamingIterator instance; never null and will never contain any null elements; however the returned instance may be empty if getNumberOfRecords() ==0.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this iterator.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.

      • entryIterator

        StreamingIterator<DataStoreEntry<T>> entryIterator()
                                            throws DataStoreException
        Create a new StreamingIterator which will iterate over all the DataStoreEntrys in this DataStore. The iteration order is guaranteed to match the iteration order by idIterator(). The StreamingIterator is only valid while this DataStore is open. If the StreamingIterator is still not finished iterating when this DataStore is closed via Closeable.close(), then any calls to StreamingIterator.hasNext() or StreamingIterator.next() will throw DataStoreClosedException.
        Returns:
        a new StreamingIterator instance; never null and will never contain any null elements; however the returned instance may be empty if getNumberOfRecords() ==0.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this iterator.
        DataStoreClosedException - if this DataStore is closed.

      • records

        default ThrowingStream<T> records()
                           throws DataStoreException
        Create a new ThrowingStream of the records in this DataStore.
        API Note:
        Jillion Version 5.3 changed the return type to be ThrowingStream instead of Stream.
        Returns:
        a new ThrowingStream.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this stream.
        Since:
        5.0

      • entries

        default ThrowingStream<DataStoreEntry<T>> entries()
                                           throws DataStoreException
        Create a new ThrowingStream of the DataStoreEntrys in this DataStore.
        Returns:
        a new ThrowingStream.
        Throws:
        DataStoreException - if there is a problem creating this stream.
        Since:
        5.3

      • adapt

        default <E,D extends DataStore<E>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                           Function<T,E> adapter)
        Convenience method to adapt this datastore into another datastore type.
        Implementation Note:
        this is the same as calling DataStore.adapt(datastoreInterface, this, adapter);
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the Class of the DataStore interface to adapt into; can not be null.
        adapter - a Function to convert an element of this datastore into the equivalent in the adapted datastore; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore; will never be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if any parameter is null.
        Since:
        5.2
        See Also:
        DataStoreUtil.adapt(Class, DataStore, Function)

      • forEach

        default <E extends Throwable> void forEach(ThrowingBiConsumer<String,T,E> consumer)
                                    throws IOException,
                                           E extends Throwable
        Iterate through all the records in the datastore and call the given consumer on each one.
        Implementation Note:
        By default, this is the same as calling: 
          try(StreamingIterator <DataStoreEntry<T>> iter = entryIterator()){
            while(iter.hasNext()){
                 DataStoreEntry<T> entry = iter.next();
                consumer.accept(entry.getKey(), entry.getValue());
            }
        }
        But datastore implementations may override this method to create a more efficient traversal.
        Parameters:
        consumer - a BiConsumer that takes the id of the record as the first parameter and the record as the second parameter.
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem iterating through the datastore.
        E extends Throwable
        Since:
        5.3

      • of

        static <T> DataStore<T> of(Map<String,T> map)
        Create a new DataStore instance using the data of the given Map. The entries in the given map are copied into a new private map so any future manipulations to the input map will not affect the returned DataStore. The order of entries return by the idIterator() and iterator() are determined by the iteration order of input Map at the time this method is called.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of Records in the DataStore.
        Parameters:
        map - the map to adapt into a DataStore.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.
        Since:
        5.3

      • of

        static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D of(Map<String,T> map,
                                       Class<D> datastoreInterface)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type D using the data of the given map. The entries in the given map are copied into a new private map so any future manipulations to the input map will not affect the returned DataStore. The order of entries return by the idIterator() and iterator() are determined by the iteration order of input Map at the time this method is called.

        This factory method uses the Java Dynamic Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which uses the map as a backing store. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given DataStore interface has extension methods that are not part of the core DataStore interface then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record in the returned dataStore and the type of the values in the given Map.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        map - the map to adapt into a datastore; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface and contains the records in the input Map.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given datastoreInterface is not a public interface or violates the constraints set by Proxy#getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)
        Since:
        5.3
        See Also:
        Proxy#getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)

      • cache

        static <D extends DataStore<?>> D cache(Class<D> c,
                                        D delegate,
                                        int cacheSize)
        Create a new Dynamic Proxy wrapping the given DataStore. The returned object is similar to the wrapped dataStore except all get(String) results are cached in an Least Recently Used (LRU) SoftReference cache of the specified size and an additional interface, CacheableDataStore has been added to the list of interfaces the returned DataStore implements. This will keep the Most recent cacheSize records in memory as long as the JVM doesn't need the memory for other things.
        Type Parameters:
        D - interface of DataStore to proxy
        Parameters:
        c - class object of D
        delegate - instance of DataStore
        cacheSize - the size of the cache used to keep most recently "gotten" objects.
        Returns:
        a proxy instance of type D which wraps the given delegate and caches all results returned by get in an LRU cache.
        Since:
        5.3
        See Also:
        #clearCacheFrom(DataStore), #isACachedDataStore(DataStore)

      • adapt

        static <F,T,D extends DataStore<T>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                            DataStore<F> delegate,
                                            Function<F,T> callback)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type T using the data of the given DataStore which contains records of the correct type. This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given interface has extension methods that do not exist in the given delegated DataStore, then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.
        Type Parameters:
        F - the "From" type. This is the type that the original datastore has its type as
        T - the "To" type. This is the type that we want to convert the type F into which may require method calls or new object creation.
        D - the Database interface type we want the returned datastore to mimic.
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        delegate - the original DataStore to adapt into a different type of DataStore; can not be null.
        callback - an instance of AdapterCallback used to adapt records of type <F> into records of type <T>; can not be null.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, delegate is null, or if callback is null.
        Since:
        5.3

      • adapt

        static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D adapt(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                          DataStore<T> delegate)
        Create a new DataStore instance of the given type D using which wraps the given DataStore in a new Dynamic Proxy class which mimics the desired DataStore. This is useful to convert a DataStore<T> into a different DataStore subinterface which has the same get(String) signature. All method calls on the returned proxy Datastore are derived by delegating to the input DataStore. Closing the input DataStore will also close this Proxy DataStore and vice versa. The order of entries return by the idIterator() and iterator() are determined by the the iteration order of input DataStore.

        This factory method uses the Java Dynamic Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which wraps the input DataStore as a backing store. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the input DataStore interface, if the return DataStore interface has extension methods that are not part of the input DataStore interface then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastoreInterface - the interface to proxy; can not be null.
        delegate - the original DataStore to adapt into a different type of DataStore.
        Returns:
        a new DataStore instance which implements the given datastoreInterface and contains the records in the input DataStore.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, delegate is null.
        NullPointerException - if datastoreInterface is null, map is null, or if any keys or values in the map are null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given datastoreInterface is not a public interface or violates the constraints set by Proxy#getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)
        Since:
        5.3
        See Also:
        Proxy#getProxyClass(ClassLoader, Class...)

      • chain

        static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> DataStore<T> chain(Collection<D> datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to get(String) or contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.
        • Calls to getNumberOfRecords() will return a combined total over all the datastores.
        • Calls to iterator() and idIterator() will chain the iterators of each DataStore one after the other. When the first datastore's iterator is finished, then StreamingIterator.next() will move onto the iterator from the next DataStore etc.
        • Closing the returned DataStore will close all the input DataStores

        This is a useful method for combining several different DataStore objects to appear as a single DataStore. For example combining several sequence input files (possibly in different file formats) which have been parsed into DataStores can be adapted into a single chained DataStore for processing. The fact that the sequence data comes from multiple files (objects) has been abstracted away.

        This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore. This factory class can only implement methods that conform to the DataStore interface, if the given interface has extension methods that do not exist in the given delegated DataStore, then trying to call those methods will throw an illegalArgumentException.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.
        Since:
        5.3

      • chain

        @SafeVarargs
static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> DataStore<T> chain(D... datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to get(String) or contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.
        • Calls to getNumberOfRecords() will return a combined total over all the datastores.
        • Calls to iterator() and idIterator() will chain the iterators of each DataStore one after the other. When the first datastore's iterator is finished, then StreamingIterator.next() will move onto the iterator from the next DataStore etc.
        • Closing the returned DataStore will close all the input DataStores

        This is a useful method for combining several different DataStore objects to appear as a single DataStore. For example combining several sequence input files (possibly in different file formats) which have been parsed into DataStores can be adapted into a single chained DataStore for processing. The fact that the sequence data comes from multiple files (objects) has been abstracted away.

        This factory method uses the Java Proxy classes to create a new implementation of the given interface which then delegates all calls to the given datastore.         Type Parameters:
        T - the type of record both the input and output dataStores.
        D - the type of DataStore to return (created using a dynamic proxy)
        Parameters:
        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.
        Since:
        5.3

      • chain

        static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D chain(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                          Collection<D> datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to get(String) or contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.

        Parameters:

        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.
        Since:
        5.3

      • chain

        @SafeVarargs
static <T,D extends DataStore<T>> D chain(Class<D> datastoreInterface,
                                                       D... datastores)
        Create a new DataStore that contains the entire contents of each of the input DataStores. The order of the input DataStores is the order that these DataStores will be chained together. This results in the following contract:
        • Calls to get(String) or contains(String) will check each DataStore for the given record until the record is found or all DataStores are checked.
        • Calls to getNumberOfRecords() will return a combined total over all the datastores.
        • Calls to iterator() and idIterator() will chain the iterators of each DataStore one after the other. When the first datastore's iterator is finished, then StreamingIterator.next() will move onto the iterator from the next DataStore etc.
        • Closing the returned DataStore will close all the input DataStores

        This is a useful method for combining several different DataStore objects to appear as a single DataStore.         Parameters:

        datastores - the datastores to chain together; can not be null or empty.
        Returns:
        a new instance of type D.
        Since:
        5.3
